column4: trying to install ubuntu on a windows machine. but i don't see automatic partitioning. I want to dual boot, how do I do this without advance partioning option
try wubi, that'll do the dual boot, no re-partitioning
I have a problem on synaptic "touchpad" utility (not the package manager)
any downside for using wubi?
AFAIK I can't enable grub2 splash screen and change its resolution
only dual boot, no more OSs with wubi, so if you're trying to do 3-boot later, it will not be an easy task
If your NTFS dies, your ubuntu dies too
thanks, but i wonder why the installer won't give me the easy partition option, the graphical partitioning
wubi makes your installation to a file inside NTFS
ah yes, i meant when i tried to install through my thumb drive
there's no partition work for wubi, it's just 1-click install
ah, i'm trying to say that before wubi i tried to install traditionally by booting up from thumb drive/cd and creating a dualboot
if you have access to paritition resizing tools, make a room and install
however grub will take over the Original Windows Bootloader
the second thing i did was use windows 7 to create an unallocated partition, and tried to install it on this but still having only 2 options: erase entire disk or advanced partitioning
is your unallocated partition inside a virtual partition?
I forgot what the other paritition is called...
i just shrunk my windows 7 partition and this resulted in an unallocated partition
/s/virtual/Extended
I have no idea sorry
i think the problem with the installer not showing automatic partioning is because its an hp computer that came with 3 other "recovery partitions"
thanks though ill keep trying

in case youre wondering i figured a solution: im using gparted to shrink instead of windows 7, this way gparted can partition into an ext4 instead of "unallocated" and the installer sees this as a free space i can install onto without me needing to mess with partition tables
